trustfund:
TF090072-SECOND VILLAGE INVESTMENT
            PROJECT IN THE KYRGYZ REPUBLIC
theme: Rural non-farm income generation,Participation and civic engagement,Rural services and infrastructure,Other social protection and risk management,Decentralization

abstracts.cdata!:
The Second Village Investment Project
            for the Kyrgyz Republic received a satisfactory outcome
            rating with moderate risk to development outcome. The Bank
            received a moderately satisfactory performance rating for
            their role in the project while the Borrower’s performance
            was rated as satisfactory. Three restructuring took place
            during the life of this project. The first restructuring:
            (i) triggered Operational Policy (OP) 4.12 on involuntary
            resettlement; (ii) clarified that the only PDO was the one
            in the financing agreement and not as slightly differently
            formulated in the project appraisal document; (iii) included
            a new results indicator to capture increased employment in
            beneficiary communities; (iv) adopted a set of new
            International Development Agency (IDA) core sector
            indicators to help capture results; and (v) extended the
            closing date for the project and the additional financing by
            six. The second restructuring (i) extended the closing date
            and additional financing by one year; and (ii) reallocated
            SDR 35,000 from category "Unallocated" to
            "Goods, Works, Training, and Operating Costs". The
            third restructuring extended the closing date by 22 months.
            The additional financing was approved to (i) finance the
            costs associated with an unanticipated financing gap
            resulting from a cost overrun in the completion of village
            investment micro-projects and (ii) retrofit a small number
            of deficient structures constructed through micro-projects.
            The second additional financing was used to fund the
            technical design and retrofitting of additional 18
            structures that could not be funded by the first additional
            financing. Several lessons are recorded from this project
            including the following: (1) the success of Village
            Investment Project (VIP2) was attributable to a number of
            good practices and measures that can be highlighted as
            valuable lessons for other community driven development
            (CDD) and local government projects, (2) a three-tiered
            quality assurance mechanism was essential to improving the
            quality of civil works, (3) repeating the micro-project
            investment cycles helped gain trust, capacity, and
            participation of community members, (4) evenly targeting all
            rural communities with small micro-projects, instead of
            focusing on selected poor communities, was an appropriate
            approach to gaining the confidence of the population, (5)
            the participatory selection process of micro-projects helped
            to increase the sustainability of small scale enterprises
            supported by VIP2, (6) establishing solid communication
            channels was key to mobilizing villagers, facilitating
            social inclusion, and increasing transparency, and (7)
            village profiles and group-specific statements of needs and
            priorities facilitated the inclusion of different social
            groups in VIP2’s micro-project activities.
